newsitem.title: USA: SEC gives final approval to NASD suitability rule.
newsitem.headline: SEC gives final approval to NASD suitability rule.

text.p: SEC approved long-awaited NASD "suitability" rules requiring government securities dealers to be more careful in sales to institutional buyers, including municipalities.
National Association of Securities Dealers rules already require dealers to have "reasonable grounds" for believing that a recommendation is "suitable" for a particular customer.
The final rules, approved Aug 20 by the Securities and Exchange Commission and expected to be announced later today, expand on that requirement as it applies to institutional buyers.

The rules come one week after Morgan Stanley & Co. settled charges that it inappropriately sold risky government securities to West Virginia's Consolidated Investment Fund, resulting in losses of $32 million. The firm agreed to pay $20 million without admitting or denying charges.
NASD's new rule says dealers should consider several things when deciding whether an institution is capable of making suitable purchases.
Does the buyer use consultants, investment advisers or bank trust departments to help steer them in the right direction? NASD says a dealer should consider.
Is the buyer experienced in financial markets and is it familiar with the instruments it wants to buy? NASD says.
Can the buyer understand an instrument's economic features, like what happens to the security when interest rates rise or fall? the new rule asks.
And dealers should consider the complexity of the security, in a provision aimed, for instance, at firms selling sophisticated derivates to localities.
NASD says a dealer can decide if a customer is making an independent investment decision using several criteria.
For instance, is there a written or oral understanding about what services the dealer is to provide? NASD says.
Does the buyer have a pattern of accepting the dealer's recommendations, the rule says.
Does the customer use ideas and information it gets from other buyers, particularly those buying the same kind of securities, the rule says.
And to what extent has the dealer received broad portfoliio information from the buyer, NASD's rule asks.
The Government Finance Officers Association (GFOA) said it is "extremely gratified" by the new rule's approval.
"The rule will go a long way in protecting the investments of state and local government taxpayers," the group said.
Congress authorized the new suitability rule in the Government Securities Act Amendments of 1993, enacted in December 1993.
An earlier version of the NASD rule was shelved after states and localities voiced strong objections, GFOA notes.
The group added that securities industry efforts earlier this year to get Congress to reverse the latest version was "thwarted."
--Vicky Stamas, 202-898-8314
